I checked your profile to see if you are another one of the Chinese profiles that keeps pushing junk investment, and I doubt a lawyer would need to buy a Turkish knockoff of a Glock, but I'll give you the benefit of the doubt that you are just a bad lawyer and can't afford anything better.

I know a good deal about China, I know about the power struggle between Xi Jinping and the Jiang Zemin faction that is causing a lot of these crackdowns. I know the Army swears allegiance to the CCP instead of the nation. That the CCP rules as the please from Zhongnanhai without regard to laws.  They are content to practice hostage diplomacy like they did with the two Michael's to free Meng Wanzhou and they seem confused when western counties can't simply disregard the courts and do as they please like China. That the Belt and Road initiative is just neo colonialism to steal resources and strategic ports from poor nations. That the Uighurs face slave labor and genocide by controlling birth rates and harvesting organs like Falun Gong practitioners. 

China is not a free, fair, or open market. Ask Jack Ma who got disappeared by them. Look at their national security laws, and how they annex neighborhoods and force their will on them. How they alter maps and globes to include the 9 dash line and pretend it is part of Chinese territory like the Scarborough shoal despite court rulings.

So tell me how elections matter when China can decide who is on the ballot to prevent a true opposition and use the national security law to disappear opposition?

Call me a typical American, but my eyes are open to the actions of the CCP.

author: moaiii
body:
That doesn't work well with options most of the time due to gamma. You could have a fairly small pullback of the underlying down to a support line or MA which will knock 50% or more off the premium almost instantly. You close, because you couldn't get a fill at 20% down, but then the underlying confirms support and shoots right back up again past your entry point bringing those premiums straight back up with them. You just lost over 50% when the trade was always above support, still trending up, and doing just fine.

Trade on the price action, not the P&L, assume that the cost/margin to enter the trade is your "at risk" amount, and set your position size accordingly.

V, MA, SQ, PYPL etc still have inflated P/E ratios(30+), while companies like GOOG are trading below 30 P/E and growing faster. So why buy an overpriced Fintech when you can buy GOOG at a much better value?

author: duskick
body: To me, SQ is an earlier version of PayPal.  They are in the process of creating their network.  The benefit they have in the long run in owning the hardware, software, and network, is that they can eliminate Visa and MasterCard from the equation.  If someone uses the Cash app to buy directly from a SQ terminal, the could reduce the charge from 2-3% (of which they get a small cut) to 0-5-1% (of which they get all).  SQ wins, merchant wins, but V and MC lose on such a transaction. PayPal is trying to build a similar network, but doesn’t have as much traction with in person terminals.

author: phohunna
body:
I live in Canada and I recently visited friends in MA where weed was legalized in 2017. Many municipalities still ban the sale.

In Boston, they have like 2 recreational dispensaries for the entire city. We had to bike nearly a half hour from Cambridge, and there were several security guards for the sleepy store. You can't buy with a credit card because the lending banks want nothing to do with it.

In Canada by contrast, its much more like a small fancy liquor store. We have dispensaries every few blocks and zero security guards. You can go in and buy with your credit card.

Companies like TLRY wont take off until there is sufficient distribution and its easy to buy. That wont come until its nationally legalized. Its going to be a long time.

author: arbiter12
body:
Ma dude... your innocence worries me so i will be harsh.

Do you really think, if the recipe for making money was "[just look for undervalued companies whereby their total share\*value is lower than their Ebitda/cashvalue!](https://corporatefinanceinstitute.com/resources/knowledge/trading-investing/trading-below-cash/)", professional trading houses would spend literal billions in research, algorithm and personnel?

&#x200B;

What you should first learn about this industry, if you want to succeed in it is that if something is easy and/or predictable, then it doesn't work/won't happen. You may get lucky and expect the expected and it happens just as planned, but most often, the big players are contrarian to the market itself, meaning that if you think A is likely and a million people think A is likely, then B is almost guaranteed to happen (unless enough contrarians think B will happen, then probably C)

Traders don't play the game fairly. They just harvest money from betting against the most number of people.

author: RumHam1
body:
Valuing a stock is really difficult and it often boils down to a lot of different assumptions.  Even experts are routinely wrong, so keep that in mind.  What I do for one company normally takes 3-5 hours, and I try to do it quarterly for any company I own.

I will usually start by collecting the company's past, current and future valuation metrics.  Things like price to sales, price to earnings, price to forward earnings, debt ratios, etc.  I compare the 5 year averages to what they currently are.  I also do for their competitors and companies in the same financial space (for example, I'd look at Visa, Mastercard, and other card companies together).  I look at past growth and projected growth to see if I think the valuations are justifiable where they currently are.

I look through the financial statements and try to spot trends in cash flow, debt, margin, and many other things to see how the company is performing yoy and qoq.

I look at how the company is engaging with the industry and where they are projecting their growth to come from.  Are the expanding market share, is the sector growing, etc.  I need the company to justify why it can achieve or surpass their growth estimates.

I listen to their most recent conference calls and look though any articles I can find, but I heavily discount opinion pieces.  I actively seek out reasons why this company will fail.

After all of this, I try to put together a balanced view of where the company is valued now vs historically and also vs their competition.  It requires a lot of projection and assumptions and I only do it for companies that I can understand their business model.  You have to go into the process without bias, and to be honest the majority of companies that I do this for aren't buys at the time.

author: dontgetmadgetdata
body:
I like it. The price is pretty elevated off it’s 50 day MA due to a nice post earnings drift. It has kissed its 50 day 5 times this year. To increase your probability of profit, I might wait until it consolidates/retraces to around this area and open up the position at that time. Possibly move the strike closer to that stock price to further increase the leverage. 

For example, If it retraces to closer to $300 level and open contracts with $280-$300 strike. You would still need around $350 to break even if the cost is halved but you would have substantially more leverage per dollar.

author: Joltarts
body:
I paint you a highly probable bear scenario.

Tesla cant meet production demand because of microchip shortages. Tesla is the most chip dependant car company out there. They will get hit by a shortage in chips to produce their cars. The prices of chips will also shoot up so high, Tesla will have no choice but to sell their cars at even lesser margins.

The green credits which Tesla depends highly on to boost their profit numbers become less attractive in 2022 and it drops significantly. A big revenue stream for Tesla is about to go out of business.

Autonomous driving experiences set back, Tesla cant deliver a workable solution and regulations ban the use of fully auto vehicles due to safety concerns.

The already crowded Tesla network is both costly to maintain and cant expand quick enough. Other players using standard charging ports catch up and overtake Tesla here. Especially in Europe and China. Since Tesla cars can only charge on Tesla ports, suddenly, Tesla cars are less attractive to own.

author: Robot_of_Sherwood
body:
# Today is Thursday, the  4th of November

author: jaedubbs
body:
Tesla has insane margins on their EVs and its clear that those margins are growing. The competition needs to sell 3+ EVs for every 1 that Tesla sells. And on top of that, Tesla produces cars in 1/3rd the time. Some OEMs are not profitable at all and each EV sold is a loss.

Also Tesla has car sales back logged for 6 months!

And a simple youtube search of FSD 10.3 shows dozens of reviews and drives of the general public. Meanwhile the competition only reveals company videos of their absolute best drives.

How about autonomous distribution?
How many self driving cars can the competition roll out to with these geofenced cars that need lidar and radar? Compare that to Tesla, which can push an over the air update and sell FSD to millions in an instant.

People keep calling Tesla just a car company, but what other car company is the:

Majority part Supplier
Dealership
Fuel provider
Microchip maker
AI developer
Software developer

author: spctr13
body:
> in fact im fairly certain all of our parts are manufactured on US soil

Down to what level though? Not many of the basic electronic components everything else is built from are made in the US. American companies like Vishay, Microchip, Texas Instruments, and Xilinx either operate factories in China or contract foundries in China or Taiwan. Other large supplies of ours are not even American such as Yageo and TE Connectivity aren't even headquartered in the US and manufacturer the bulk of their product in their home country. It's been a big issue for my portion of the defense industry the past couple of years because these factories in China are also sourcing a large portion of counterfeit electronic components on the market.

I know we're not the only defense manufacturer using Chinese components because I've seen several news articles and reports from the DOD claiming this is a problem.

https://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2020/dec/10/us-military-reliance-china-foreign-suppliers-expos/

Panasonic and Murata (Japanese) used to produce critical components of our products, but have since stopped selling to us because they don't want their products used in munitions. When that happened the government fronted a lot of money to a couple American companies to produce an alternative since none existed.

author: high_roller_dude
body:
growth stocks. esp mid cap tech, before they moon. 

Feb of 2020, my account was at $300k at the peak. then covid happened and things went to hell in March 2020. at the trough my account dipped to $200k.

as of today my account is north of $900k. how did i get there? mix of mega cap (msft) and a basket of mid cap tech (net, crwd, se, mdb, etc)

always be on the look out for promising young companies whose market cap is less than $20B. barbell that with some safe assets like msft. 

embrace risk, and learn to live with volatility. that is what i can tell you. good luck

author: Mysterious----
body: Best part is you can’t say market isn’t built on only speculation when MSFT quarterly growth in EPS Was less than 4% but it’s share price is up 17% quarter over quarter and its revenue is down. It’s all cash injected growth from the fed pumping market prices. Inflation hasn’t even hit Main Street. Wait until the 2.5x leveraged markets deleverage and the money hits. Add on the great resignation and worker shortages which will eat into corporations margins, supply chain issues, and the housing market crisis slowly unfolding. There is no way the SPY doesn’t hit $500 EOY.

author: ProteinEngineer
body:
I have never had a VR experience that I think would increase work efficiency.  I think Zuckerberg is so far removed from what it's like working an actual job or living a normal life that he thinks it's a good idea.

In terms of facebook/instagram: It seems like every 5-10 years, a new app comes around that replaces the previously popular one.  Instagram is being replaced by Tik Tok with younger users. Nobody young wants to be on facebook anymore now that it's filled with geriatrics, so FB is much more instagram heavy than in the past for younger users, and reliant on some really politically controversial groups to extract money out of facebook. Yes, they currently have a stranglehold on social media advertising, but I think their "moat"  is nonexistent compared to companies like Amazon, Apple,  Google, and Microsoft. Apple, Amazon, and Google especially-those are three exceptionally innovative companies compared to FB.

author: tall_investor
body:
Interesting.

I'm sure people thought Microsoft was impervious to competitors as well and along came Apple.

Facebook owns social media. While this does make it subject to the whims of the hardware it is run on, and you bet monopolistic companies like Apple want to eventually get into that sphere, FB still has a monopoly on what we use our devices for.

I swear, we live not in the apple, Microsoft, or amazon age... but the Instagram age.

Recently I have come around with regards to the metaverse - I think it is the terrifying step towards us living in VR as all the future dystopian movies showed us. I really could see us working and logging into a meta verse to allow WFH while still having more supervision than we currently have.

Also, agreed. Thought it was ridiculous when the author said they changed their name to metaverse to distract from the bad press... You seriously think they'd change their name to an even scarier name and that that would distract the press? You think they would make such an enormous decision in a matter of weeks or months?

author: Glad-Marionberry-634
body: Finally someone advising to buy actually strong companies. Personally I hold msft (best investment yet) and Intel. Baba will probably come back so I don't blame anyone for buying/holding it, I just don't. Everyone else in this thread is advising to buy more meme stocks, id say take any profits you've made and walk away, eventually people will need their money that's tied up in those and you don't want to be a bag holder. MSFT is probably the safest and most solid tech company right now with the best credit, and tons of cash, etc, etc basically hard to find weak spots. If this person really wants serious advice I'd say count your blessings and get out of the meme stocks and into lower risk, maybe some etfs. There are a lot of sectors that were ignored that are poised to do well. If you really want individual stocks maybe NOK or RYAAY. Those are in a similar risk/reward range to their current portfolio but with a little more stability.

author: throwwayhubu
body:
CRSR wasnt listed back when Cathy Woods et al hatched their revenue- and profit-averse plan to pump every speculative dumpsterfire of a stock that could present a way to give goods and services for free or at a loss to its users. In the short term, if CRSR wants to improve its share price, they need to dump their cash cows on an established firm like MSFT and launch a crypto-based multi-level marketing scheme that promises to end climate change and require a vaccine pass.  
  
 In the long term, CRSR is looking like one of the juicier fundamental plays in the markets, they are riding a strong macro trend in gaming and media, streamers have essentially replaced TV for people 6-20 years of age and gaming is probably the most common hobby of that generation and tends to be kept up over the years. The only future headwind I see is continued expansion and innovation in their product lines, their position in components like memory would ideally be follow up with stronger positions in other peripherals and potentially software.

author: ybnesman

author: MvCSpiderman
body:
People don't get why Tesla is going up because they have no idea how the market works or what to look at.

$TSLA is up due to retailer mass consolidation. Ten(well now 9) stocks are basically pushing the three major indexes as people spend the last two years tired of figuring out charts, being burned by earnings and memes, and the recent higher prices for goods which give them less to spend.

Tesla is one of those 9 stocks. That's it.

In fact at this point 60% of retail are in these 9 stocks. All it takes is to manipulate one of them by a decent amount and the whole thing crumbles.

People are stubborn and make themselves believe they are causing the upward trends in the etfs or Tesla when they aren't. Tesla can drop to $400 in a couple days if institutions wanted it to. Many are already diversifying outside the most popular stocks the last two years (with some exceptions like MSFT).

Keep an eye on institutions during the FED meeting the next two days, you are going to see gradual movements to make it not seem obvious that they are preparing to take advantage of the dive.

If you are in Tesla now and over $100k+ in profits then take it out. Don't hold at this point. There isn't time to correct after the FED meeting as you will likely be priced out. Puts will be much more expensive in the next couple weeks for high value stocks.

author: TheNewOP
body: You're expecting a rebound. That may not happen, the 2020 crash rebound is not a rule. There are plenty of stocks that trade sideways for 5 years, and the tickers you named are not immune to that. The market was basically trading sideways from 2000-2013. Microsoft traded sideways for 10 years. Your LEAPS would've either expired worthless or you would've been bled by theta. But if you bought shares all of those years, you would've had a ~13 bagger. Meanwhile your LEAPS in total would be down by God knows how much. Options are a form of market timing and risky, and that includes LEAPS, a year is nothing if compared to buying and holding.

author: Alcapwn-
body:
It’s not rocket science, but trying to get rich quick tends not to end well unless you’re lucky or are given extremely good advice from people who know the tricks of the trade. 

I’m a rank amateur at this game. I have three kids, aged 14, 12, & 10. About 7 years ago they were each given 10k from their grandpa to open an investment account. I opened an account for each them here in Australia trading on the ASX. I’ve only purchased blue chip shares that pay 4-10% returns year in year out, and all those dividends are reinvested back in to those stocks when issued. Each birthday I give them $1000 to add to their portfolios, and $1000 each at Xmas. The eldest two are sitting on almost 75k each, and the youngest is just under 70k. 

By the time they’re 21 and have access to their accounts, they should have around 150k perhaps more if the bank of mum and dad don’t raid it🤣. It gives them a leg up to start their lives. They’re not allow to blow it on cars etc, they can use a bit for travel, but I’m hoping it can get them in to the property market and or keep the portfolio going until they’re much older. They’ve had one really lucky break with one share which has doubled and makes up good slice of their portfolio and pays big dividends each year. That aside it’s been pretty basic investments. If it was the US market it would stocks like MSFT, CRM, TSLA, AAPL that I’ve tipped money in to. So relatively low risk and just playing the long game and I’ve not sold a single share in that time. 

Christ I wished my parents had done a similar thing for me and my sisters when I was young.

author: gabugabuchan
body:
Great product with potential, trash management.

Some people might disagree with me on the great product part, because they think it's just an art board. But there's more to it, it's a mommy-dominated social media platform and it's the 14th largest in the world at that, with 454 million monthly active users. The user base is there, the influence is there, the potential is definitely there. There's a reason why Microsoft was willing to pay a premium of roughly 86 per share to acquire the company.

Which leads us to why the stock is falling, they didn't get acquired, which means that they believe they can grow it better than the 86 per share valuation, but then in a span of less than a year, the management managed (pardon the pun) to drive the stock price down to half or less than half of what Microsoft originally offered due to their management.

With the reason you mentioned, bad guidance attributed to covid reopening, and the disappointing earning reports over the last 2 quarters. I wouldn't be touching this stock anywhere at this price.

author: Lewodyn
body:
If you believe Microsoft is going to beat the market by a significant amount, then buy microsoft otherwise go with a broad market fund. I am not talking about the company, but about the stock. Microsoft stock has a significant premium. 

For most ppl, especially beginners, a passive strategy is advised. Set and forget. You don't need a lot of knowledge to passively invest; just buy every month and trust that the market will go up in the longterm, like it has in the past. 

When buying a fund, two things are vital. The holdings and the costs. Make sure that the cost is below 0.3%, there are some funds below 0.1%. Plus make sure that the holdings contains a lot of stocks from different sectors with a good spread (e.g. not 80% is in tesla). Plus you could also diversify with including different regions. You might want to consider an all world fund, like vt.

author: dcahill78
body:
You are totally correct on In 2 ways I’m living in Ireland so 1.16 million dollars would make me a millionaire here. Also our version of the IRS is just called Revenue, no tax on the unsold Tesla shares. Hobby trading options call could be 33% or if what I’ve done in 2 years is looked at as professional really all my realised gains this year get taxed at 41%. 

Problem is our revenue don’t have clear cut rules, as in x trades per year or gains over x amount is income vs CGT. I would totally like to have a simple balanced account my next purchase is probably 100k of Microsoft, BRKb, Amazon and Apple but I wouldn’t let go of of a single Tesla share, they mean to much to me now.

author: yeppersbruh
body:
A deal that is worth about $5B is announced, not even signed yet.

>Market Cap increases by about $300B

CEO makes sure to tell people the deal isn't even signed yet, additionally 12.000 cars are getting recalled

>Market Cap decreases by about $40B pre market

This is an absolute joke. What the fuck is going on? Tesla seems to be the OG Meme stock. This is absolutely insane and not rationally justifiable. Tesla isn't worth half of Microsoft and Apple. It just isn't. At least not today, at least not on a risk adjusted basis. I'm just speechless at this point.
